headline.main: A Long and Winding Road Together

results.snippet: Changes and more changes, but with a little help, Calif Green has kept his four boys together and has them poised for adulthood.

multimedia.caption: The Neediest Cases | Generations of Giving

legacy.MultimediaHeadline1: The Neediest Cases | Generations of Giving

results.lead_paragraph: The one constant in Calif Green's 36 years has been motion. A life that began in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, took him to North Carolina; Bay Ridge, Brooklyn; New Orleans; Atlanta; central Florida; prison; Macon, Ga.; Maryland; Key West, Fla.; a Harlem shelter; and ultimately, a three-bedroom apartment on the Rockaway peninsula so close to Kennedy Airport that, every three to five minutes, a plane will buzz the 11-story apartment building, its engines visible from the living room window.

results.abstract: Katie Spotz will attempt to become youngest person to c√ø
results.snippet: Katie Spotz will attempt to become the youngest person to cross an ocean in a rowboat, and the youngest American to row solo from mainland to mainland.
results.lead_paragraph: This winter, Katie Spotz plans to cross the Atlantic Ocean without a sail or a motor. Through 50-foot waves and hurricane-force winds, the only thing propelling her tiny yellow boat will be Spotz's arms pulling against two black oars. In the small but growing sport of ocean rowing, even the smallest sail is considered cheating. So Spotz, 22, will row at least 2,500 miles without even a tarp to protect herself from the sun, lest she be tempted to use it to catch the wind.

results.abstract: An astronaut has resigned his long-running chess game with a group of Washington school children.
results.snippet: An astronaut has resigned his long-running chess game with a group of Washington school children.
results.lead_paragraph: In the end, the astronaut could not outwit the children.

FILM SERIES 'CITY LIGHTS' AND 'MODERN TIMES' (Monday through Wednesday) This series features Charlie Chaplin's last two films without spoken dialogue (with their elaborate scores and sound effects, they are hardly silent), released (in 1931 and 1936) long after the rest of Hollywood had given up on the silent cinema. Both films are deeply engaged in the social and economic realities of the Great Depression, which, if anything, makes them timelier today. In ''City Lights'' Chaplin is a citizen of the streets who goes from sleeping in the arms of a civic statue to fighting back his impossible love for a blind flower girl. ''Modern Times'' imagines him almost literally as a cog in the gigantic machine of American capitalism, a factory worker who befriends an orphan (Paulette Goddard) and dreams of the open road. Walter Reade Theater, 165 West 65th Street, Lincoln Center , (212) 975-5600, filmlinc.org. Single tickets: $11; $8 for 62+; $7 for students and children. Both films: $15; $11 for 62+; $9 for students and children. (Dave Kehr)20091217

results.abstract: Joshuah Bearman Op-Ed article recounts youthful lesson in art of futures investments when he realized he could trade promise of slices of his mother's layer cake, not yet baked, for existing sweets in lunchboxes of fellow students; like all marketing bubbles, his could not last forever, and was doomed by friend who figured out that number of cake slices promised defied physics of any layer cake known; remembers ending up alone, snackless, on monkey bars; drawing (M)
results.snippet: Recalling the youthful exuberance of Rice Krispie treats and fruit roll-ups, the creator of a bizarre lunchroom derivatives bubble spins a parable for our economic times.
results.lead_paragraph: ''SARDINES are better than candy,'' my father said. ''They're oily, but nutritious!'' Easy for him to say. I was 8 and had just moved to a new, fancier school. The socioeconomic shift was most apparent to me in the cafeteria, where there was a wide disparity between my lunch and everyone else's. Ours was a Spartan household: no chocolate, cookies or extraneous sugar. For us, Rice Krispies cereal was supposed to be some kind of special indulgence.

results.snippet: To meet its new goals for human spaceflight, NASA should launch early and launch often.
results.lead_paragraph: IN Silicon Valley we have a saying: launch early, launch often. It's an acknowledgment that successful, innovative companies are the ones that rapidly try new ideas, see what works, improve their products and repeat. Businesses that launch frequently are also able to take advantage of economies of scale to make launchings faster and easier. In many ways, the key to innovation is speed of execution.

headline.main: A Symbiotic Friendship of Mechanical Precision

results.snippet: Watch brands have started using their craftsmanship and technological advancements to benefit the many industries they have been affiliated with over the years.
results.lead_paragraph: PARIS -- The luxury watch industry has been picking favorites for years. Watch brands have long linked themselves so closely to the same sporting events and institutions that it is hard to imagine one without the other. Think of Omega, and the Olympics or NASA comes to mind. Mention Breitling and talk turns to airplanes or Bentleys. The TAG Heuer brand will forever be tied to automobile races. The company Ulysse Nardin has tethered itself to the nautical world and sea sports.

results.snippet: 8 P.M. (Nickelodeon) KIDS TO THE RESCUE! HELPING HOMELESS ANIMALS ''Nick News With Linda Ellerbee'' looks at children from across the country, including a few close to home in Brooklyn and New Rochelle, N.Y., who have come to the aid of some of the...
results.lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Nickelodeon) KIDS TO THE RESCUE! HELPING HOMELESS ANIMALS ''Nick News With Linda Ellerbee'' looks at children from across the country, including a few close to home in Brooklyn and New Rochelle, N.Y., who have come to the aid of some of the hundreds of thousands of cats and dogs that have been abandoned during the recession. It also tells the stories of celebrities who have welcomed rescued animals into their homes, including Lance Bass, Sophia Bush, Kellan Lutz, Tony Hawk, Tiffani Thiessen and Bonnie Hunt. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOSRobert Gibbs, the White House press secretary, discusses where the Obama administration stands on the issues that divide the House and Senate health care reform bills and what the president's priorities are for 2010. Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky, weighs in on his party's strategy heading into the new year. Mr. Gibbs moves to ''Meet the Press,'' at 10:30 on NBC, alongside Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York; Newt Gingrich, the former House speaker; and Gov. Deval Patrick of Massachusetts.

results.abstract: Neil Genzlinger column fondly recalls time, when he was child, when there were only three television networks and he could marvel, innocently, at special effects on old television series; notes advent of DVD, with super slow motion, has taken his innocence away; photos (M)
results.snippet: DVDs of beloved old shows  “F Troop,” “The Munsters” and others  have destroyed a small boy’s sense of wonder.
results.lead_paragraph: The death of the DVD continued in 2009, and it can't come soon enough for me. Those wretched round devils have destroyed a small boy's sense of wonder. Many years ago, in the blissful days of three and only three networks, that boy -- i.e., me -- would watch the offered television fare and be amazed by the bravery of the actors and the magical qualities of the land in which lived, a land where things like the rules of gravity seemed to be optional. For decades this innocent awe somehow sustained the boy as he meandered into adulthood and the drabness of real life. ''Sure,'' he would tell himself, ''the car battery is dead and the medical bills are unpaid, but it's O.K. because somewhere hats can fly off people's heads straight up, and a girl can shoot bottles out of midair.''

results.abstract: Sally K. Ride, a former astronaut, has long pushed to close the persistent gender gap in math, science and engineering education as part of the private sector. Now she is an emissary for a federal program that seeks to address the problem.

headline.main: Math, Tech and the Women Who Don't Love Them

results.snippet: Sally K. Ride, a former astronaut, has long pushed to close the persistent gender gap in math, science and engineering education as part of the private sector. Now she is an emissary for a federal program that seeks to address the problem.
results.lead_paragraph: It's no secret to anyone in Silicon Valley that math, science and technology fields remain dominated by men, despite some progress by women in recent years. Women make up 46 percent of the American workforce but hold just 25 percent of the jobs in engineering, technology and science, according to the National Science Foundation.

results.abstract: Vietnamese court convicts former Army officer Tran Anh Kim of subversion for pro-democracy activities and sentences him to five and half years in prison; trial of four other activists is scheduled for January (M)

headline.main: Vietnam Sentences a Dissident to 5 Years in Prison as Part of a Crackdown

results.snippet: A court on Monday convicted Tran Anh Kim of subversion for pro-democracy activities and sentenced him to five and a half years in prison.

byline.original: By SETH MYDANS and MARK McDONALD; Seth Mydans reported from Bangkok, and Mark McDonald from Hong Kong

results.lead_paragraph: The first in a series of trials of dissidents in Vietnam concluded Monday when a court convicted a former army officer of subversion for pro-democracy activities and sentenced him to five and a half years in prison. The conviction of the former officer, Tran Anh Kim, 60, comes as the government is tightening controls on dissent in advance of a Communist Party congress in early 2011.

results.abstract: Dennis Overbye Essay explores unknown elements of physics and revels in process of discovery (M)

headline.main: The Joy of Physics Isn't in the Results, but in the Search Itself

results.snippet: The search for the meaning of the universe may lead to inventions whose purpose is often ambiguous.
results.lead_paragraph: I was asked recently what the Large Hadron Collider, the giant particle accelerator outside Geneva, is good for. After $10 billion and 15 years, the machine is ready to begin operations early next year, banging together protons in an effort to recreate the conditions of the Big Bang. Sure, there are new particles and abstract symmetries in the offing for those few who speak the language of quantum field theory. But what about the rest of us? The classic answer was allegedly given long ago by Michael Faraday, who, when asked what good was electricity, told a government minister that he didn't know but that ''one day you will tax it.''

results.abstract: Russian space agency head Anatoly Perminov says top country's top space researchers will hold closed-door meeting to plan mission to deflect 99942 Apophis, asteroid that will fly close to Earth by 2032; Apophis is about three times size of Tunguska meteorite, apparent cause of 1908 explosion in Siberia that knocked over estimated 80 million trees; NASA has downgraded chances of asteroid hitting Earth (M)

headline.main: Russia to Plan Deflection Of Asteroid From Earth

results.snippet: Russia’s top space researchers will hold a meeting to plan a mission to deflect 99942 Apophis, an asteroid that could conceivably hit the Earth two decades from now.
results.lead_paragraph: Russia's top space researchers will hold a closed-door meeting to plan a mission to deflect 99942 Apophis, an asteroid that will fly close to Earth two decades from now, said Anatoly N. Perminov, the head of Russia's space agency, during an interview on Russian radio on Wednesday. Mr. Perminov said Apophis, named for the Egyptian god of destruction, is about three times the size of the Tunguska meteorite, apparently the cause of a 1908 explosion in Siberia that knocked over an estimated 80 million trees. He said that according to his experts' calculation, there was still time to design a spacecraft that could alter Apophis's path before it made a dangerous swing toward Earth.
